body: Report `rdkit` version because I don't trust you guys anymore, updating to some new stuff that's broken :P

```
[joao@computer02 ~]$ conda list | egrep rdkit
rdkit                     2017.09.2.0      py36hf4eed20_1    acellera
```
I don't see any limitation on rdkit version on the repo though

Ok that one should work. There is no limitation but we only ship that one from acellera so by default you cannot get a newer one unless you try to be clever. In any case, this seems like an rdkit issue, not a moleculekit one.

issue.title: Molecules in getVoxelDescriptors()

repository.name: moleculekit
repository.description: MoleculeKit: Your favorite molecule manipulation kit

issue.body:
Hi devs,

I have a short question to the Topic getVoxelDescriptors. Like mentioned in Issue #12, sometimes it is not possible to create a SmallMol. I am trying to reproduce the KDeep-paper. You said me already, that during the dev of the paper, the SmallMol-Class does not exist and you use the Molecule-Class.

Well If I create the Molecule class from a ligand, than I get an Error in getVoxelDescriptor(), that my Mol is not a protein.
Is the only option, the deactivation of the validitychecks?
How I get a similar result like it was used in the 'old' package. 

If this is not possible, I think I have to use the old version of the package. But then I need to have my data in the ptbqt-format form AutoDock4. Can you give me a hint, how you have converted the files in the ptbqt-format?

body:
I see, the issue is in the hydrogen fixing of rdkit.
If you do this it works fine. 
```python
sm = SmallMol('1a1e_ligand.mol2', force_reading=True, removeHs=False, fixHs=False)
```
The fixing puts the hydrogen at [0, 0, 0] coordinates. 

My suggestion for the moment would be to try to protonate the molecules with some other software and then load the mol2 with all the hydrogens using SmallMol and the above options.

@j3mdamas I fixed the error when trying to read the sdf. Now it correctly just prints the rdkit error and reports that it failed to load the molecule 
https://github.com/Acellera/moleculekit/commit/12b60abb3c2bda12dac0f20765ca90c20ca89543
```
In [1]: from moleculekit.smallmol.smallmollib import SmallMolLib 
   ...: sml = SmallMolLib('1a1e_ligand.sdf')                                                                        
  0%|                                                                                         | 0/1 [00:00<?, ?it/s][21:41:48] Explicit valence for atom # 25 C, 6, is greater than permitted
[21:41:48] ERROR: Could not sanitize molecule ending on line 152
[21:41:48] ERROR: Explicit valence for atom # 25 C, 6, is greater than permitted
100%|████████████████████████████████████████████████████████████████████████████████| 1/1 [00:00<00:00, 104.12it/s]
2019-06-04 21:41:48,718 - moleculekit.smallmol.smallmollib - INFO - Failed to load 1/1 molecules
```

Added option to disable rdkit sanitization of the sdf files https://github.com/Acellera/moleculekit/commit/b4d58011ecc3247bd65e45434eca836d0f1f0a30
```
In [1]: from moleculekit.smallmol.smallmollib import SmallMolLib                                                    

In [2]: sml = SmallMolLib('1a1e_ligand.sdf', fixHs=False, removeHs=False, sanitize=True)                            
  0%|                                                                                         | 0/1 [00:00<?, ?it/s][21:54:01] Explicit valence for atom # 25 C, 6, is greater than permitted
[21:54:01] ERROR: Could not sanitize molecule ending on line 152
[21:54:01] ERROR: Explicit valence for atom # 25 C, 6, is greater than permitted
100%|█████████████████████████████████████████████████████████████████████████████████| 1/1 [00:00<00:00, 70.80it/s]
2019-06-04 21:54:01,950 - moleculekit.smallmol.smallmollib - INFO - Failed to load 1/1 molecules

In [3]: sml = SmallMolLib('1a1e_ligand.sdf', fixHs=False, removeHs=False, sanitize=False)                           
100%|████████████████████████████████████████████████████████████████████████████████| 1/1 [00:00<00:00, 215.58it/s]
```

who made these `mol2/sdf` files? They have the S and C marked as double or aromatic bonds to all oxygens.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7935362/58906572-df7b3480-8714-11e9-93c8-a5945bb8eec4.png)

So my conclusion is that input files are simply broken. Either the atom types are bad or the bonds are bad. This causes rdkit to fail and in my opinion it gives decent warnings ala `[22:12:23] 1a1e_ligand: warning - O.co2 with non C.2 or S.o2 neighbor`. If someone can provide the source of these files or how they were generated it would be great, otherwise I will close the issue.

The data are from the PDBbind-dataset. This is the dataset, which was used in the KDeep-paper of your group. Because I want to reproduce the results of the paper as baseline for masterthesis, I have to use this data. You can get the data here http://pdbbind.org.cn/. In this case, this are data from the refined set of 2016.

From around 3700 data for the training-set of the NN, 1200 leads to this errors.
One of the supporter of the HTMD has said, that during the dev of this paper, no SmallMolecule class was avaible and I should use the Molecule-class instead. Like mentioned in issue #13 this seems not as a good idea. So how I can get the voxelized data for the NN with your software?

`sm = SmallMol('1a1e_ligand.mol2', force_reading=True, removeHs=False, fixHs=False)`

This kind of stuff is working for some of the data. The first question I have is maybe a little bit stupid, but there are hydrogen in the files. Does this not mean, that they are allready protonated?

But nevertheless, there are some files, which I can not read in, also with this trick. For example the complex "1ols" failed to read with this.

So in general, there must be an option, to get the voxelised data with features for the ligands, to reproduce the results of KDeep. In the paper they mentioned, that HTMD is the software, which can be used to get these. But actually I can not see, how I can do this. Or better how should do this.

Maybe you have an idea, what is the fastest way to get the voxelised data for the network.


So this comment is an combination from this issue and the closed issue #13.

I'm sorry but I cannot help you clean the PDBbind dataset. To me the dataset looks pretty broken.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7935362/58937627-a3c78580-877b-11e9-9634-d8e8c193ee04.png)
Look at the hydrogens at the right, they are all over the place.
So the hydrogens are wrong, and you cannot remove+guess them with rdkit because the atom types and the bonds are wrong as well.

with the latest github version of moleculekit you can read the sdf files like this:
```python
allmols = []
for ff in glob('./*.sdf'):
    allmols.append(SmallMolLib(ff, sanitize=False, removeHs=False, fixHs=False)[0])
```
But I don't see the point in reading them in with the hydrogens as they are wrong.

Only thing I can suggest you is to find some software that can fix the bond types and the hydrogens of the ligands and then read it in with smallmol. Maybe autodock tools can do it since we used that for the paper.

Is the dev of the KDeep related to moleculekit? Maybe he can help with an short introduction, how he have done this? Maybe there is an very easy path in autodock for this? I never used autodock before, so I do not know.
http://autodock.scripps.edu/faqs-help/how-to/how-to-prepare-a-ligand-file-for-autodock4
Thinking about it, this will not really work. Autodock has it's own atom types and pdbqt format which rdkit cannot read. You need to find some other way to fix the hydrogens and bonds in PDBbind.

Well. But the old version of HTMD want to have ptbqt for the getVoxelDescriptor(). So I could use the old version for the ligands and use this script to transform ligands in ptbqt.
But nevertheless, in general, I need a fixed version of the files for further projects.

Maybe one could use this prepare_ligand and then convert the pdbqt back to a mol2 file.
I have no idea if this is working, but I would try. 
If this is working, I would add a comment here. Maybe one could create a python function out of this procedure and integrate this in HTMD. For the future, this could be helpful.
Yes, you can use the above script I posted to prepare the ligands with autodock, it also has one for proteins. Then load them with Molecule and use `getVoxelDescriptors` with `version=1`
I doubt you will be able to convert the pdbqt to a working mol2 file. `rdkit` is peculiar about the atomtypes it wants.

Maybe a small info.
I wrote a function, which uses pybel and firstly convert the mol2 file 
to a pdbqt format.
After this, it convert the pdbqt in a pdb-file.
This can be read in with the SmallMol-class, without force-reading.

For all SmallMols I can create the voxelised features.

There is an exception for one ligand file. I do not know, why it fails. 
But 1 of 3700 is better than 1380 of 3700.

Actually also the proteins leads to some errors. Maybe we can shortly 
discuss this.

I use the following Code:
`
prot = Molecule(Path_To_Prot)
prot.filter('protein')
prot.bonds = prot._getBonds()
voxeldescriptors.getVoxelDescriptors(prot)
`

This results in the error boolean index did not mathc indexed array 
along dimension 0,
dimension is 234 but corresponding booleand dimesnion is 4644

If I use:
`
prot = Molecule(Path_To_Prot)
prot.filter('protein')
prot.bonds = prot._getBonds()
prot = prepareProteinForAtomtyping(prot)
voxeldescriptors.getVoxelDescriptors(prot)
`

I get the following error:

`  File "/home/max/anaconda3/lib/python3.6/site-packages/moleculekit/tools/voxeldescriptors.py", line 195, in getVoxelDescriptors
    channels, mol = getChannels(mol, aromaticNitrogen, version, validitychecks)
  File "/home/max/anaconda3/lib/python3.6/site-packages/moleculekit/tools/voxeldescriptors.py", line 90, in getChannels
    sigmas = _getChannelRadii(mol.get('element'))
  File "/home/max/anaconda3/lib/python3.6/site-packages/moleculekit/tools/voxeldescriptors.py", line 61, in _getChannelRadii
    radii = np.array([periodictable[e].vdw_radius for e in molelements])
  File "/home/max/anaconda3/lib/python3.6/site-packages/moleculekit/tools/voxeldescriptors.py", line 61, in <listcomp>
    radii = np.array([periodictable[e].vdw_radius for e in molelements])
KeyError: 'SE'`

Maybe you have an idea.

The point is in general, that the prepareProtein-function changes the molecule. In KDeep, binding affinities are predicted. If I change the protein in some way, then the binding-affinity is maybe not correct anymore.

This could also mean, that if some bounds or hydrogens are fixed in AutoDock4, that the binding-affinities are not correct to the "fixed" molecule. Because you do not know, which bondtype is wrong and which you have to fix. Same for hydrogens.

Maybe here could just the deactivation of validitychecks help? Just put this stuff in the voxelisation? What do you think about this.

I would write the pdbbind-support a mail and would inform them. Maybe they also have an idea.

BTW. The error-message above is from the protein of complex "1gz4" of the dataset

Well. Some of the errors with this dataset for the proteins can be solved by converting. 

The error with the 'SE' is, that the software reads Selenium sometimes with SE instead of Se. I do not know why, but it can fixed for my data with `prot.set(value='Se', field = 'element', sel='name SE')`.

I tested acutally 500 complexes. With this two points, I could fix all but of of them which raises an error.

Maybe a much more interesting part would be, that at one of my files (of my tested, actually I do not have tested all 3700 complexes) has the problem that if I prepare the protein before voxelisation  with `prot = prepareProteinForAtomtyping(prot)`. Leads to the error.

_________________________________________________________________________________

~/anaconda3/lib/python3.6/site-packages/moleculekit/tools/voxeldescriptors.py in getChannels(mol, aromaticNitrogen, version, validitychecks)
     83         elif version == 2:
     84             from moleculekit.tools.atomtyper import getFeatures, getPDBQTAtomTypesAndCharges
---> 85             mol.atomtype, mol.charge = getPDBQTAtomTypesAndCharges(mol, aromaticNitrogen=aromaticNitrogen, validitychecks=validitychecks)
     86             channels = getFeatures(mol)
     87 

~/anaconda3/lib/python3.6/site-packages/moleculekit/tools/atomtyper.py in getPDBQTAtomTypesAndCharges(mol, aromaticNitrogen, validitychecks)
    163     charges = ['{0:.3f}'.format(a[-1]) for a in atomsProp]
    164     pdbqtATypes = [getPDBQTAtomType(a[3], n, mol, aromaticNitrogen)
--> 165                    for n, a in enumerate(atomsProp)]
    166 
    167     return np.array(pdbqtATypes, dtype='O'), np.array(charges, dtype='float32')

~/anaconda3/lib/python3.6/site-packages/moleculekit/tools/atomtyper.py in <listcomp>(.0)
    163     charges = ['{0:.3f}'.format(a[-1]) for a in atomsProp]
    164     pdbqtATypes = [getPDBQTAtomType(a[3], n, mol, aromaticNitrogen)
--> 165                    for n, a in enumerate(atomsProp)]
    166 
    167     return np.array(pdbqtATypes, dtype='O'), np.array(charges, dtype='float32')

~/anaconda3/lib/python3.6/site-packages/moleculekit/tools/atomtyper.py in getPDBQTAtomType(atype, aidx, mol, aromaticNitrogen)
     53         # print(aidx)
     54         # print(np.where(mol.bonds == aidx))
---> 55         bond = np.where(mol.bonds == aidx)[0][0]
     56         oidx = [a for a in mol.bonds[bond] if a != aidx][0]
     57         if mol.element[oidx] not in ['C', 'A']:

IndexError: index 0 is out of bounds for axis 0 with size 0


____________________________________________________________________________
Without perparation it works. Is this a Bug in the preperation-function?

issue.title: SIGSEGV-Error

repository.name: moleculekit
repository.description: MoleculeKit: Your favorite molecule manipulation kit

issue.body:
Hi Devs,

I have found a new problem. Maybe this is worth a new ticket.

I have observed, that sometimes the call of getVoxelDescriptors leads to a SIGSEGV-Error. After reading through this error, it seems, that this is often a software-sided problem. Did you have experience with this?

body:
Which version are you using of moleculekit? The issue with the element names is solved as far as I'm concerned in the last version.

Don't disable the validity checks. The option is only there for performance reasons if all your data is already perfect and you don't want to waste time doing the checks.

The error you get means that there are no bonds in the molecule which is very weird. Do a `%debug` when it throws the error in `ipython` and check what the `mol` object contains and do `mol.view(guessBonds=False)` which will show the structure with the bonds it contains (probably not bonds, just dots in space). Then you can figure out why the bond guessing failed. My guess is that the structure is probably broken or empty.

Also as a general suggestion to get better answers online, keep the error reports a bit more concise otherwise it's hard to answer to so many questions over so many posts. Thanks anyway for the interest and the reports :)

I use the last version. Maybe this is a bug, but I think not part of this ticket. For me I have found a solution to fix this.

For the bond-guessing error, this comes from the prepareprotein-method. The not prepared protein passes all validitychecks. But this seems as an very rare event. I can not say, if this is a bug. But also here I "fix" this and do not use the prepare function for the small number of proteins.

Thank you for your help. Next time I will pay attention to this.

Maybe the SmallMol thing is fixed. If the other problems are bugs and not part of the data, then this is a new ticket I think. From my side, this can be closed.

Ok I could replicate the selenium issue. The proteinPrepare was reading the elements from pdb2pqr and not capitalizing them correctly.

I fixed it here https://github.com/Acellera/moleculekit/commit/c9af624a0943e105b754bc252f16bd40157f39c2
Thanks a lot for the report!
